questions.text: The image below shows a KOH mount of sputum collected from an immunocompromised patient. Based on the microscopic findings, identify the most likely causative organism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows characteristic microscopic findings of Aspergillus species.

The first image shows the characteristic appearance of dichotomous branching or acute angle branching in a KOH mount, and the second image shows the characteristic appearance with conidiophores having vesicles with lactophenol cotton blue stain.

  • Aspergillus is an opportunistic fungus.
  • One of the key diagnostic features of Aspergillus species is their dichotomous branching of the conidiophores.
  • Conidiophores in Aspergillus species often branch in a dichotomous manner, meaning that the branches fork evenly, usually at an angle of 45° or so, forming a "Y"-shaped structure.
  • This is a distinctive feature in the identification of Aspergillus under the microscope when preparing a KOH mount.
  • Aspergillus conidiophores can also have chains of conidia at the tips of these dichotomously branching structures.
  • Aspergillus causes opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals.

Explanation of other options:

Zygomycetes (Option A): Zygomycetes include Rhizopus and Mucor. They typically have non-septate hyphae without cross-walls and show random, irregular branching. Zygomycetes are more commonly recognised by their sporangia and sporangiophores, not by dichotomous branching.

Candida (Option C): Candida species can form pseudohyphae, which are chains of yeast cells that elongate but do not branch dichotomously. Candida species form germ tubes with growth factor when incubated in human serum at 37 degrees Celsius. This phenomenon is called the Reynold Braude Phenomenon.

Cryptococcus (Option D): Cryptococcus is a capsulated yeast that generally grows as budding yeast cells and does not form hyphae.

Fig: Gram staining of Cryptococcus neoformans showing Gram-positive round budding yeast cells.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with itching and ear pain. Otoscopic examination revealed black debris in the external auditory canal, as shown. A culture of samples collected from the ear on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar showed colonies as shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario, along with culture showing powder black colonies, suggests otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger.

Otomycosis is a superficial fungal infection of the external auditory canal.

Common causative agents are Aspergillus and Candida species.

Clinical features:

  • Irritation and itching are the most predominant symptoms of Aspergillus niger infection.
  • Pain is predominant in Aspergillus flavus infection.
  • The fungal mass in otomycosis is likened to a wet blotting paper/wet newspaper appearance.

Otoscopy findings:

  • Black-headed filamentous growth - Aspergillus niger infection
  • Green or brown - Aspergillus fumigatus infection
  • White and creamy deposits - Candida infection.

Laboratory findings:

Microscopy:

  • On a 10% KOH mount, Aspergillus shows septate hyphae with branching at acute angles and conidia at the ends of conidiophores.

Culture: (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar medium)

  • Colonies typically grow rapidly and consist of hyaline septate hyphae from which conidiophores arise, which end at vesicles.
  • Colony appearance of various Aspergillus species is:
    • Aspergillus fumigatus: Smoky green, velvety to powdery colonies (Fig. A)
    • Aspergillus flavus: Yellow, green, velvety colonies (Fig. B)
    • Aspergillus niger: Black, cottony type colonies (Fig. C)

Explanation of other options:

Actinomycetes (Option A): Actinomycetes typically cause chronic infections presenting with abscesses, draining sinuses, and granulomas; their colonies appear grayish-white to yellow with a molar tooth or granular appearance, and microscopy reveals branching filaments with sulfur granules.

Zygomycetes (Option C): Zygomycetes, such as Rhizopus oryzae, cause mucormycosis, commonly presenting as rhino-orbital-cerebral infection. Colonies are initially white to grey, later turning brown or black. Microscopy shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching.

Cryptococcus (Option D): The causative agent of cryptococcosis is Cryptococcus neoformans, which can lead to meningitis, pulmonary infections, and disseminated disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Colonies appear mucoid or glossy due to a thick capsule, and India ink preparation reveals encapsulated yeast cells with a clear halo highlighting the polysaccharide capsule.

Fig: Mucoid colonies of Cryptococcus in SDA medium

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aspergillus species are rapidly growing moulds that are frequently isolated from the environment and are thus common causes of infections in patients with severe immune-compromising conditions.
  • The most common cause of infections in humans is A fumigatus, but other species, such as A flavus, A niger, and A terreus, may less frequently cause human disease.
  • Direct Examination in KOH (10%) mount or histopathological staining of specimens reveals characteristic narrow septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching.

Culture:

  • Specimens are inoculated onto SDA and incubated at 25°C. Species identification is done based on macroscopic and microscopic (LPCB mount) appearance of the colonies.
  • Colonies consist of hyaline septate hyphae from which conidiophores arise, which end at vesicles.
  • From the vesicle, finger-like projections of conidia-producing cells arise, called phialides or sterigmata.
  • Conidia arise from the vesicles either on their entire surface or only on the upper half.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoing chemotherapy for leukaemia presents with fever, cough, and haemoptysis. Chest imaging showed a halo sign with ground-glass opacity. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Respiratory symptoms along with halo sign in chest imaging of an immunocompromised individual suggest invasive aspergillos is caused by Aspergillus species, which are multicellular fungi.

  • Aspergillus is a zygomycete with broad, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphae that branch at acute angles. (Option A ruled out)
  • Aspergillus is a multicellular mould that reproduces asexually through conidiospores.
  • Various Aspergillus species produce several fungal toxins; e.g. A. flavus produces aflatoxin, which causes hepatocellular carcinoma. (Option D ruled out)
  • Aspergillus manifest in four primary clinical forms, largely determined by the host's immune status:
    • Invasive aspergillosis - common in immunocompromised individuals.
    • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis - seen in patients with asthma, cystic fibrosis, and bronchiectasis
    • Aspergilloma - occurs in pre-existing lung cavities, as in TB
    • Aspergillus pneumonia

Invasive aspergillosis:

  • Symptoms include fever, cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis.
  • Hyphae invade the lumens and walls of blood vessels, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis.
  • From the lungs, the disease may spread to the gastrointestinal tract, kidney, liver, brain, or other organs, producing abscesses and necrotic lesions.
  • Invasive aspergillosis occurs in highly immunocompromised persons, often rapidly resulting in death. (Option C ruled out)

Risk factors for invasive aspergillosis are:

  • Glucocorticoid use (the most important risk factor)
  • Profound neutropenia
  • Immunocompromised individuals
  • Anti-tumour necrosis factor therapy.

Radiology findings:

  • Halo sign on a thoracic CT scan - a localised ground-glass appearance representing hemorrhagic infarction surrounds a nodule or consolidation.
  • Other characteristic radiologic features of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis include nodules and pleural-based infarction or cavitation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of COVID-19 and uncontrolled diabetes presents with significant visual impairment. The clinical picture of the patient's face is given below. Imaging showed bony erosion, orbital involvement and soft tissue necrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate line of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation is suggestive of rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis, and the treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B.

  • Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia.
  • Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis.
  • It starts as eye and facial pain, may progress to cause orbital cellulitis, proptosis and vision loss.
  • Causes black eschar due to angiothrombosis.

Risk factors for the infection include:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Old age
  • Defects in phagocytic function. (e.g. neutropenia or steroid therapy).
  • Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation.
  • Patients with renal insufficiency
  • Iron supplementation

Laboratory findings:

  • Histopathological staining, such as H&E or methenamine silver stain of tissue biopsies, shows broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching.
  • Culture on SDA at 25°C: Reveals characteristic white cottony woolly colonies with tube filling growth (hence called lid lifters).
  • In some species, e.g. Rhizopus, the colonies become brown black later, due to sporulation, giving rise to salt and pepper appearance.
  • Microscopic appearance: LPCB mount of the colonies reveals broad aseptate hyaline hyphae.

The treatment of choice is Liposomal amphotericin-B.

Fig: LPCB mount of colonies of A) Rhizopus showing sporangium with rhizoid present; D) Mucor shows sporangium (absence of rhizoid).

Explanation of other options:

Itraconazole (Option A), Fluconazole( Option D): These azole group of antifungal agents are mainly effective against Aspergillus and Candida species and are not suitable for mucormycosis, as they are typically resistant to azole antifungals.

Corticosteroids (Option B): While corticosteroids are used in certain inflammatory conditions, they suppress the immune system and can worsen fungal infections like mucormycosis. In this patient, corticosteroids should be avoided.

choices.text: Iron supplementation is recommended in infected patients
Patients on dialysis are at increased risk

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Zygomycetes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Iron supplements should not be given in cases of Zygomycetes, as iron promotes their growth.

  • Iron overload can promote the growth of Zygomycetes (such as Rhizopus), particularly in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis or those receiving iron supplements.
  • Since high iron levels in tissues enhance the virulence of the fungi, iron supplementation is contraindicated in these infections.

Risk factors for zygomycetes infection:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Old age
  • Defects in phagocytic function. (e.g. neutropenia or steroid therapy).
  • Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation.
  • Patients with renal insufficiency
  • Iron supplementation

Explanation of other options:

Rhizopus has nodal rhizoids (Option A): Rhizopus species are characterised by the presence of nodal rhizoids, which are root-like structures that emerge from the junctions (nodes) of the hyphae. Lichtheimia species bears internodal rhizoids, while rhizoids are absent in Mucor.

They exhibit vertical branching (Option C): Zygomycetes typically exhibit vertical branching (right-angle branching) of their aseptate hyphae.

Patients on dialysis are at increased risk (Option D): Patients on chronic dialysis, especially those receiving iron therapy or deferoxamine, are at higher risk of mucormycosis. Additionally, dialysis patients often have underlying immunosuppression or diabetes, further increasing their vulnerability.

questions.text: A 28-year-old HIV patient presents with fever, chills, shortness of breath and cough with frothy sputum. Chest X-ray revealed interstitial infiltration, and the microscopy image of bronchoalveolar lavage is shown below. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microscopy revealing a crushed ping pong ball appearance, in the context of respiratory symptoms in an HIV-positive patient, is suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia.

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii is a ubiquitous coloniser of the human airway.
  • Pneumocystis exists as cysts and trophozoites.
  • It commonly affects immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with AIDS, and results in lethal pneumonia.
  • Cysts are inhaled from the environment and convert to trophozoites in the lungs, triggering a plasma cell-rich inflammatory response and frothy alveolar exudate, hence the term plasma cell pneumonia.

Clinical features:

  • Initial symptoms include fever or malaise.
  • Respiratory symptoms come later with cough and shortness of breath.
  • Frothy exudates are a classic feature of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), which often presents with frothy, pink, or blood-tinged sputum.
  • The infection typically causes bilateral interstitial infiltrates(ground-glass opacities) that are commonly seen on chest X-rays of patients with PCP.

Microscopy findings:

  • Crushed ping-pong ball appearance: This is a classic finding seen on histological examination or microscopy of Pneumocystis jirovecii in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Gomori's methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black coloured crushed ping-pong balls against the green background.

Explanation of other options:

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option B): Cryptococcus causes meningitis or lung infections, especially in immunocompromised patients. However, it does not present with the frothy exudates or the interstitial infiltrates seen in this case. Cryptococcus shows negative staining with India ink stain on the CSF sample.

Fig: India ink staining of Cryptococcus showing a retractile capsule

Mucor (Option C): Zygomycetes cause mucormycosis, a rapidly progressive infection seen in immunocompromised, especially diabetic patients and undergoing immunosuppressive therapy, presenting with necrotic sinusitis or pneumonia. It often leads to black necrotic tissue, and chest X-ray shows consolidation or cavitation, not interstitial infiltrates.

Candida glabrata (Option D): Candida glabrata is an opportunistic yeast that can cause candidiasis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. It commonly causes bloodstream infections and mucosal infections. Candida cultures on SDA show white, pasty colonies.

Fig: White to cream smooth colonies on Candida in SDA

choices.text: Lesion typically involves skin and subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Botryomycosis is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Botryomycosis:

  • Botryomycosis is a chronic, purulent, granule-producing, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues and visceral organs.
  • The condition is caused by bacteria; the most common organism implicated is Staphylococcus aureus. (Option A, D ruled out)
  • Clinically and histopathologically, it resembles Mycetoma.
  • Infection is characterised by a neutrophilic reaction.
  • Treatable with antibiotics. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms shows the microscopic finding shown below?

1. Candida albicans
2. Candida non-albicans
3. Candida dubliniensis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows Germ tube formation (the Reynolds Braude phenomenon) seen in Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis.

Germ tube test:

  • It is a specific test for C. albicans, also called the Reynolds Braude phenomenon.
  • This phenomenon involves germ tube formation when certain Candida species are incubated in serum at 37°C for 2 hours.
  • It is differentiated from pseudohyphae as there is no constriction at the origin.
  • Though the test is specific for albicans, it may also be positive for C. dubliniensis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old HIV-positive male with a CD4 count of 50 cells/mm3 presents with a 2-week history of fever, headache, confusion, and neck stiffness. On examination, he is febrile and disoriented with signs of meningeal irritation. CSF analysis shows an elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of lymphocytes, low glucose, and elevated protein levels. The latex agglutination test for capsular antigen in CSF is positive. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture described is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis, which is common in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with advanced HIV/AIDS and CD4 count <100 cells/mm3.

  • Cryptococcus species grow as a budding yeast, and the most characteristic feature of these cells is a large polysaccharide capsule.
  • The most important clinical manifestation of cryptococcal disease is a life-threatening meningitis in immunocompromised patients.
  • The clinical onset is slow, even insidious, with low-grade fever and headache progressing to an altered mental state and seizures.

Individuals at high risk for cryptococcosis include:

  • Patients with advanced HIV infection with CD4 + T cell counts less than 200/µL.
  • Patients with hematologic malignancies
  • Transplant recipients
  • Patients on immunosuppressive or steroid therapy.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • Negative staining: India ink stain is used to demonstrate the capsule, which appears as a retractile, delineated, clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells against a black background
  • Antigen detection: The capsular antigens can be detected from CSF or serum by the latex agglutination test. It is a rapid and sensitive (95% sensitivity) and specific method.
  • Culture:
    • Mucoid, creamy white colonies on SDA
    • Brownish black colonies on niger seed agar
  • Positive urea hydrolysis test.

Explanation of other options:

Candida (Option B): Candida species typically cause mucosal or systemic infections in immunocompromised individuals. While Candida can cause meningitis, it is much less common than cryptococcal meningitis, especially in the setting of HIV/AIDS. Diagnosis is usually via culture or microscopy, not latex agglutination of CSF.

Aspergillus (Option C): Aspergillosis, caused by Aspergillus species, mainly presents as pulmonary or invasive systemic disease in immunocompromised hosts. CNS involvement is rare and usually manifests as brain abscesses, not meningitis. It is usually identified by culture, histopathology, or serologic tests for galactomannan antigen detection (but not by latex agglutination).

Histoplasma (Option D): Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, more likely to affect the lungs, and it can disseminate to other organs in immunocompromised patients. Histoplasmosis is diagnosed using cultures, serologic tests, and detection of Histoplasma antigen (usually in urine or serum)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for cryptococcal infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals; renal transplant recipients are vulnerable to cryptococcal infection due to the prolonged use of immunosuppressive drugs.

Individuals at high risk for cryptococcosis include:

  • Patients with hematologic malignancies
  • Recipients of solid organ transplants with ongoing immunosuppressive therapy
  • Persons whose medical conditions necessitate glucocorticoid therapy
  • Patients with advanced HIV infection and CD4+T lymphocyte counts of <200/L

Explanation of other options:

Agammaglobulinemia (Option B): Agammaglobulinemia is a primary immunodeficiency disease characterised by a lack of antibodies, but it primarily increases susceptibility to bacterial infections rather than fungal infections like cryptococcal meningitis. Fungal infections, including cryptococcosis, are more closely associated with cell-mediated immunity defects (e.g., T-cell dysfunction).

Neutropenia (Option C): While neutropenia does increase the risk for infections with bacteria and fungi (such as Aspergillus), it is not as strongly associated with cryptococcal meningitis as conditions like HIV/AIDS or organ transplantation.

IgA deficiency (Option D): Deficiency of IgA primarily impacts mucosal immunity (e.g., in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts).

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms matched correctly with their stains?a) Mucicarmine - Cryptococcus
b) Giemsa - Candida
c) Methenamine silver - Histoplasma
d) Gram stain - Pneumocystis carini
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mucicarmineis a special stain used to highlight capsules of Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast that has a characteristic polysaccharide capsule. Mucicarmine stains the capsule bright red, helping in the identification of the organism.
  • Methenamine silveris a special stain that stains fungi, including Histoplasma capsulatum, which causes histoplasmosis. It highlights the fungal elements in tissue, making it useful for diagnosing fungal infections.
  • Giemsastain is typically used for blood and bone marrow smears, and helps identify malaria parasites and leishmania.
  • Candidaspecies can be stained with Gram's stain or Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS).
  • Gram stainis not effective for diagnosing Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii). Instead, special stains like Giemsa, Silver stain, or Toluidine blue are used to identify this organism.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive woman presents with a painful, indurated ulcer on the lateral border of her tongue. Microscopic examination of the lesion showed budding yeast with pseudohyphae, and incubation in human serum at 37°C demonstrated germ tube formation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An oral ulcer in an immunocompromised patient, along with findings like pseudohyphae and germ tube formation, is diagnostic of Candida albicans, a common opportunistic fungal pathogen.

  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal disease in humans, affecting the skin, mucosa, and various internal organs; caused by Candida, a yeast-like fungus that produces pseudohyphae.
  • Candida albicans is the most pathogenic species of Candida infecting humans.
  • Candida species produce a spectrum of infections ranging from skin and mucosal infections to invasive and allergic infections.
  • Candidiasis can present with mucosal manifestations like oral thrush and vulvovaginitis, as well as cutaneous forms such as intertrigo and nail infections like paronychia and onychomycosis.

Laboratory findings:

  • Gram staining of the colonies shows Gram-positive budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae.
  • Culture on SDA produces creamy white and pasty colonies.
  • Germ tube test:
    • It is a specific test for C. albicans, also called the Reynolds Braude phenomenon.
    • When incubated at 37°C and in the presence of serum, C. albicans rapidly forms elongated hyphae called germ tubes.
  • Candida albicans can grow well on cornmeal agar at 20°C, and it often shows characteristic chlamydospore formation, which is a feature of this species.
  • β-d-Glucan antigen is a marker of invasive fungal infections; it is raised in invasive candidiasis.

Fig: A) White creamy colonies Candida; B) Germ tube formation

Explanation of other options:

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option B): Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that grows as a mould at 25°C and as a yeast at 37°C. It also does not grow on cornmeal agar. It causes histoplasmosis, which mainly involves the lungs.

Blastomyces dermatitidis (Option C): This dimorphic fungus causes blastomycosis. It forms broad-based budding yeast at 37°C but does not typically show hyphal growth on cornmeal agar.

Coccidioides immitis (Option D): Coccidioides immitis grows as a mould in the environment and forms spherules in tissue. It does not show the budding yeast form typical of Candida and does not grow on cornmeal agar. Coccidioidomycosis can cause a chronic and fatal meningitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old farmer presents with a 10-day history of pain and blurring of vision in the left eye following trauma with vegetative material. Slit-lamp examination revealed a corneal ulcer with a creamy infiltrate with feathery margins and satellite lesions. Microscopy from corneal scraping shows branching aseptate hyphae and sickle-shaped macroconidia. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's ulcerative corneal lesion following trauma with vegetative matter strongly suggests a fungal aetiology, and microscopy findings are indicative of Fusarium infection.

  • Fungal corneal ulcers present as an ulcerative lesion with a raised creamy infiltrate and feathery margins on examination.
  • The presence of satellite lesions indicates that the infection is spreading.
  • It often follows trauma with organic material (e.g., plant matter).
  • Fungi commonly responsible for mycotic corneal ulcers are Aspergillus (most common), Candida and Fusarium.

Fusarium:

  • Fusarium species are soil and plant saprophytes found worldwide.
  • In immunocompetent individuals, they cause keratitis in contact lens wearers and onychomycosis.
  • Fusarium is a filamentous fungus, grows rapidly on SDA at 25°C and produces woolly to cottony, flat, spreading white to pink colonies.
  • LPCB mount of the colony reveals hyaline septate hyphae bearing round microconidia, sickle-shaped large macroconidia and chlamydospores.

Fig: Fusarium species (LPCB mount).

Explanation of other options:

Aspergillus (Option A): Aspergillus is the most common cause of fungal keratitis, but Aspergillus typically presents with septate hyphae (with cross-walls), and the conidia are more round or globose, not sickle-shaped as seen with Fusarium.

Mucor (Option C): Mucor is a zygomycete and can cause corneal infections, but it usually affects immunocompromised patients and presents with non-septate hyphae.

Dermatophytes (Option D): Dermatophytes cause superficial skin infections, usually in the form of ringworm, and are not associated with deep corneal infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient on chemotherapy for leukaemia presents with persistent fever and respiratory distress and is unresponsive to antibiotics. Serum β-D-glucan assay is positive. Which of the following fungal infections is least likely to be detected by this assay?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

β-1-3 Glucan assay is a marker of invasive fungal infections, raised in all invasive fungal infections, except for zygomycosis, blastomycosis and cryptococcosis.

  • Beta-D-glucan is commonly used as adjunctive evidence to diagnose invasive fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients.
  • Diagnosis is challenging in such patients because blood cultures are often negative, and since tissue biopsy, the gold standard for diagnosis, is risky due to possible complications of bleeding.
  • β-d-Glucan is found in a broad range of fungal agents, including the commonly encountered agents Candida spp., Aspergillus spp., and Pneumocystis jirovecii.
  • Beta-D-glucan cannot be used to identify infections by Cryptococcus, Blastomyces or Zygomycetes such as Mucor, or Rhizopus since these species either do not produce beta-D-glucan or produce low levels that might lead to false negatives.
  • Most patients with an invasive fungal infection have serum β-glucan levels above 80 pg/mL. Normal levels are 10-40 pg/mL, and a negative test may exclude mycotic disease.
  • β-d-Glucan antigen can be detected in blood by colourimetric enzyme immunoassay.
  • Cross-reactions with certain hemodialysis filters, beta-lactam antimicrobials, and immunoglobulins can give false-positive tests.

Explanation of other options:

Invasive Candidiasis (Option A): Candidiasis is caused by Candida species, which can lead to invasive infections in immunocompromised patients. Their cell walls contain β-1,3-glucan, making them detectable by the β-1,3-glucan assay, a useful tool for diagnosing invasive candidiasis, especially candidemia.

Invasive Aspergillosis (Option B): Aspergillosis is caused by fungi of the Aspergillus genus, which contain β-1,3-glucan in their cell walls. The test offers high sensitivity for detecting invasive Aspergillus infections.

Pneumocystis Pneumonia (Option C): Pneumocystis jirovecii is the causative agent of Pneumocystis pneumonia, a fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. The organism also contains β-D-glucan in its cell wall.

Key Takeaways:

The β-d-Glucan assay is a marker of invasive fungal infections, raised in all invasive fungal infections, except for Zygomycosis, blastomycosis, and cryptococcosis. Used for the diagnosis of the following invasive fungal infections:

  • Invasive Candidiasis
  • Invasive Aspergillosis
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia

questions.text: Galactomannan antigen test in a patient's serum or urine is used for the diagnosis of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The galactomannan antigen test is highly specific for Aspergillus species.

  • The presence of galactomannan in the serum or urine indicates an invasive aspergillosisinfection, which is a significant concern, especially in immunocompromised patients leukaemia patients, stem cell transplants, or those on immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Both β-d-Glucan and Galactomannan antigen can be used for the diagnosis of Aspergillus species.

Explanation of other options:

Candida (Option A): Candida infections are usually diagnosed using culture, microscopy, or specific tests such as beta-D-glucan assays, but galactomannan is not used for Candida.

Mucor (Option B): Mucor and other Zygomycetes (e.g., Rhizopus) do not contain galactomannan. Therefore, the galactomannan antigen test is not used for diagnosing Mucor infections.

Cryptococcus (Option D): The diagnosis of Cryptococcus (particularly cryptococcal meningitis) is typically done using cryptococcal antigen testing (CrAg) or India ink staining. Cryptococcus also gives positive latex agglutination tests.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female gardener presents with a 3-week history of painless, slowly enlarging nodules on her right forearm. She now has multiple similar lesions along her forearm, which eventually ulcerated. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of sporotrichosis, a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii.

  • Sporothrix schenckii infections are commonly associated with those involved in gardening, handling plants, and exposure to soil.
  • It causes sporotrichosis, also known as Rose Gardner's disease, which presents as subcutaneous noduloulcerative lesions along lymphatics.
  • Hallmark microscopy findings in the biopsy specimen from lesions are asteroid bodies.
    • Asteroid body consists of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic mass, composed of antigen-antibody complexes.
    • Such an eosinophilic halo is described as the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.
    • Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is also observed in zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis and blastomycosis.
  • Treatment typically involves oral itraconazole, which is the first-line therapy for most cases of sporotrichosis.

Explanation of other options

Candidiasis (Option B): Typically caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans. It presents with symptoms like red, itchy rashes, oral thrush, or vaginal yeast infections. Topical nystatin is used for treating cutaneous candidiasis, but it would not be effective for a deep tissue fungal infection like sporotrichosis.

Blastomycosis (Option C): Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, a dimorphic fungus found in moist soil, especially in North America. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms such as cough, fever, and chest pain. Amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for severe or disseminated cases.

Histoplasmosis (Option D): Causative agent is Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus found in soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings, particularly in the Midwestern United States. It typically presents with respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, fever, chest pain) after inhalation of fungal spores. Oral fluconazole is often used to treat.

questions.text: Match the following dermatophytoses with their characteristics:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory form of tinea capitis, presenting as a painful, boggy swelling of the scalp. It is commonly caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and mentagrophytes. The hair perforation test is typically positive with T. mentagrophytes.
  • Tinea corporis affects non-hairy, smooth skin and presents as circular, pruritic patches with an advancing red border and central clearing with scaling. Common causative agents are Trichophyton rubrum and Epidermophyton floccosum.
  • Favus is an acute form of tinea capitis characterised by cup-like crusts (scutula) surrounding infected hair follicles, with minimal hair shaft involvement and is caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.
  • Jock itch refers to Tinea cruris, which involves the Most such infections involve males and present as dry, itchy lesions that often start on the scrotum and spread to the groin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer presents with progressively enlarging, painless nodular and ulcerative lesions on his leg. On examination, discharging sinuses with serous discharge containing granules were noted. He was empirically started on antibiotics but showed no clinical improvement. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation of painless swelling with discharging sinuses containing granules unresponsive to antibiotics is characteristic of eumycetoma, most commonly caused by the fungus Madurella.

  • Mycetoma, also known as Maduramycosis, Madura foot is a chronic, slowly progressive granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues.
  • Clinically present as a triad of swelling, discharging sinuses and presence of granules in the discharge.
  • Mycetoma is of two types:
    • Eumycetoma caused by fungal agents such as Madurella mycetomatis
    • Actinomycetoma is caused by bacterial agents such as Nocardia.
  • The causative agents enter the skin or subcutaneous tissue from the contaminated soil, usually by accidental trauma such as a thorn prick or splinter injury.
  • Feet are the most common site affected, although any site can be involved.
  • Lesions are usually painless.

Explanation of other options:

Nocardia (Option A): Nocardia is a filamentous bacterium and causes actinomycetoma. Actinomycetoma presents with multiple swellings with discharging sinus with yellow coloured sulphur granules. They respond well to antibiotics.

Sporothrix (Option C): Sporothrix schenkii causes sporotrichosis, which presents are nodular ulcerative lesions along lymphatics, commonly following thorn prick injuries. It is not characterised by discharging sinuses.

Fonsecaea (Option D): Fonsecaea pedrosoi and F. compacta are dematoaceous fungi known to cause chromoblastomycosis. They present as slow-growing ulcerative subcutaneous lesions. Histopathological appearance of these fungi is characterised by sclerotic bodies.
